results: TJC(R, I) holds for some ring R with an ideal I such that the I-adic topology on R is Hausdorff and R/I is a subring of a Q-algebra.
JC(R) holds for all rings R which are subrings of a Q-algebra.
TJC(R, I, n) is false when R/I has positive characteristic.
title: A Tate Algebra Version of the Jacobian Conjecture.pdf
abstract: . This paper investigates a Tate algebra version of the Jacobian conjecture, referred to as the Tate-Jacobian conjecture, for commutative rings R equipped with an I-adic topology. We show that if the I-adic topology on R is Hausdorﬀand R/I is a subring of a Q-algebra, then the Tate-Jacobian conjecture is equivalent to the Jacobian conjecture. Conversely, if R/I has positive characteristic, the Tate-Jacobian conjecture fails. Furthermore, we establish that the Jacobian conjecture for C is equivalent to the following statement: for all but ﬁnitely many primes p, the inverse of a polynomial map over Cp whose Jacobian determinant is an element of C× p lies in the Tate algebra over Cp. Introduction The Jacobian conjecture (JC), ﬁrst proposed by O.-H. Keller in 1939 [6] and later included among Smale’s problems, concerns the invertibility of polynomial maps over a commutative ring R under the assumption that their Jacobian determinant is a unit in the polynomial ring. Given a polynomial map F = (f1, . . . , fn) ∈R[X1, . . . , Xn]n, its Jacobian matrix is deﬁned by JF =  ∂fi ∂Xj  1≤i,j≤n . The conjecture, referred to as JC(R, n), asserts the following: If F ∈R[X1, . . . , Xn]n satisﬁes det JF ∈R[X1, . . . , Xn]×, then there exists G ∈R[X1, . . . , Xn]n such that F ◦G = G ◦F = (X1, . . . , Xn). JC(R, n) In this paper, JC(R) refers to the conjunction of JC(R, n) for all n ≥1. The existing results on the Jacobian conjecture depend on the characteristic of the ring R. Here, R is said to have characteristic c, where c is a nonnegative integer, if the kernel of the unique homomorphism Z →R is the ideal c Z. • Characteristic zero case: E. Connell and L. van den Dries [3], together with H. Bass, E. Mutchnik, and D. Wright [1], proved that for any integral domains R and S of characteristic zero, JC(R) is equivalent to JC(S).
